title: Blue Mesa Summit
text:
Blue Mesa Summit (elevation ) is a mountain pass in <a href="Gunnison%20County%2C%20Colorado">Gunnison County</a> of west-central <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>. The pass is traversed by <a href="U.S.%20Route%2050">U.S. Route 50</a> and divides the watersheds of <a href="Little%20Cimarron%20River">Little Cimarron River</a> to the west and <a href="Blue%20Creek%20%28Gunnison%20River%20tributary%29">Blue Creek</a> to the east.
History.
Blue Mesa Summit had long been used by <a href="Ute%20People">Utes</a>, trappers, and explorers who were traveling between the <a href="Gunnison%2C%20Colorado">Gunnison Valley</a> to the east and the <a href="Uncompahgre%20Valley">Uncompahgre Valley</a> to the west. By the mid-1870s, mining in the San Juan Mountains resulted in the construction of trails and wagon roads connecting the increasing number of new mining camps and growing towns. Road builder <a href="Otto%20Mears">Otto Mears</a> had constructed the Saguache and San Juan Toll Road connecting the towns of <a href="Saguache%2C%20Colorado">Saguache</a> and <a href="Lake%20City%2C%20Colorado">Lake City</a> in 1874. Needed was a road connecting this route to the mining town of <a href="Ouray%2C%20Colorado">Ouray</a> to the west. Mears’ new Lake Fork and Uncompahgre Toll Road was opened in 1878, and it followed the established trail over Blue Mesa Summit.
In the 1930s, the newly designated <a href="U.S.%20Route%2050%20in%20Colorado">U.S. Route 50</a> was routed over Blue Mesa Summit and the location follows closely the historic toll road over the pass.
